snapshot:
Chen Hosting

Checklist

Here's the list of things I'm working on (as well as the things I've completed) just as a reminder for me and as a way for you to figure out where I am with improving the service and opening up to new customers.

  • SFTP accessiblity
  • New payment system
  • Host migration
  • Website re-design
  • Outgoing E-mail
  • I2P service
  • Shell service
  • Registration and ticket interface
  • Website stats and configuration
  • Mailing list?
  • Clearnet hosting

Update

Below is an E-mail I have sent to all current users of the hosting service. You can also download the .eml file and read it using your favourite mail client. Responses are welcome; just send them to wowaname@volatile.ch.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

(If you're in a hurry, at least read the "Immediate changes" a few
paragraphs down.)

Hi all,

This is the first mass-mail I've sent to everyone I have on record, and
I believe it is a fairly important update. I will probably create an
optional mailing list for those who want to keep track of important
updates such as this, and so I can manage E-mail addresses more
efficiently ... right now, I just have your addresses in a text file.

Anyways, a bit of personal background: I left college, and as a result I
have more time to focus on maintaining this service, working on my code
projects, and finding a real-life job (this hosting I only do for fun
and to pay for the servers I rent). What does this mean for you? I'll be
able to focus on drastically improving the hosting service. I've had a
few hiccups in the past -- one in January where the service flatlined,
and one in the past month where service has slowed down and user
accounts were inaccessible. Last month I moved all websites to a VPS
hosted by Legionbox, a Russian reseller. I chose Legionbox because I was
in a rush to get things going, and I thought I could get a good deal
with them if I helped rewrite their website to look less like it came
from Google Translate and more like it was written professionally by a
native English speaker. Turns out, the provider sucks, the connection is
horrid (dropped packets all the time), the support crew's solution to
issues is to restart the box (hello, I kind of depend on the uptime), et
cetera.

Anyways, I bought a new VPS with an undisclosed but dependable provider,
recommended by a friend. I took extra precaution with this one because I
have time to spare now, and because I want this to last. I firewalled
the box so nothing can connect to it except with Tor or I2P, and nothing
can go out of it except through Tor or I2P. I protected the VPS from
basic attacks e.g. from federal agents who may decide to seize a server
(the chance of this happening in the first place should be very slim,
since I try to be meticulous about security). I won't go into detail
with this because I want everyone to understand that my server is not a
place for any of you to put highly sensitive information on -- not that
any of you would do that.

I have run this new VPS for long enough to tell that the support is
decent, the networking is decent, the RAM and disk specs should be
enough for my current number of users (and if it isn't, I can always
spin up another VPS and allow new users there). And it's not connected
to my personal identity at all, so I'll be in the hosting business for a
while longer. Speed should no longer be an issue, downtime should no
longer be a worry, and you all won't have much reason to complain about
bad service like I have regrettably served in the past.

Immediate changes and notices:

*	By the time you read this message, SFTP should be accessible again. I
apologise for the inconvenience that has caused for some users who
weren't able to upload files to their sites.
*	Also, since I have had a lot of things come up, I am indefinitely
suspending any payments you owe for your site -- don't even try to give
me bitcoin unless it's an anonymous donation. That's the least I can do,
and it's easier for me until I can organise my payment system a bit.
*	And of course, we have changed hosts again. I don't forsee having to
change hosts again unless we are compromised (unlikely), our current VPS
provider stops providing service (unlikely), or I have to move your site
because the small VPS simply does not have enough resources (I don't see
this happening for a while).

Since I have more time to work on things, this is what I look forward to
doing in the near future before opening up to new users again:

*	I will (finally) get outgoing E-mail working for sites that need it.
All mail will go through Tor so my server's IP address remains secret
and so using it for spam is pretty pointless. I expect it to be used for
E-mail verification or password reset forms, not for webmail services
like Torbox and SIGAINT. (I plan to set up my own free clearnet/Tor mail
service anyway.)
*	I will resume I2P service once I figure out the needed firewall rules
to allow Tor and I2P to coexist on the same server.
*	I will provide limited shell service so you can, for instance, upload
a zip file and unzip it on the server, or download a forum software
directly from the server without having to upload it using your own
connection. I have to be very careful about this before I allow people
to use it, though. There is an entire book of attacks on the server that
one can do with shell access. I have to make sure people don't abuse
resources and run background processes (bitcoin miners, for instance) on
the shell.
*	I will provide an easier registration and ticket interface so I can
keep track of people and requests more easily, and so you and new users
can register sites without asking me twenty questions about how the
prices work ;p
*	I'll also try to make website statistics work better; I have had some
issues with trying to check everyone's disk usage and bandwidth. Also, I
would like to provide saner configurations for websites -- I don't know
if the Tor2Web proxies are an issue to you all, but it's something I
would like to support better.
*	As I have mentioned earlier, I may start a mailing list for anyone
interested in service updates; the usefulness of a mailing list remains
to be seen. In any case, I'll work on making it easier for us to contact
each other should issues ever arise.
*	I plan to expand into the clearnet realm for those who want their
sites showcased to users outside of Tor and I2P. Of course, I will have
to regulate this because legality and DDoS becomes a HUGE concern once
an IP address is tied to a website. This means absolutely no scam sites
(I mind my own business for onion sites most of the time, you're
welcome), and it means I have to tread really lightly with borderline
illegal content such as drug/crime/paedophilia discussion. It will be a
balancing act between my desire for free speech and my desire not to get
into legal trouble.

I believe I covered all that I wanted for now. All that remains is going
through with my promises, slowly progressing since this is a lot of
stuff and I want to get it right. My foremost concern is and has always
been keeping websites up and running. And with Cyrus, the main hosting
contender, sadly out of the picture, there are only a few other reliable
hosts to choose from. I came into the hosting scene because I want to
make a difference in Tor, and while I certainly get tired of the markets
and scams popping up (yes, I'm talking about some of you as well) I
still keep going because I know there will always be an occasional
person who wants to set up a site and make a difference. And if they
don't trust themselves to set up a secure, Tor-only server, they look to
someone else who can set one up for them. That's where I come in and try
to help.

If you have any questions about what I have said, any criticisms about
what I suggested, or any new suggestions you believe would improve Chen
Hosting, you're more than welcome to reply. Thanks for sticking around.
--=20
wowaname
https://wowana.me/pgp.htm


--WPmwxaG2W7aUgSHOWaPflRwqtrJHbQjU6
